text: FATHE NOORI: I got

after I coming back
from work to my area.

I was working with the United
States Army in Afghanistan

as interpreter, so I was really
close with the hiring officers
from the Army and Air Force.

One time, the--
the Taliban, they

were trying to kidnap
my wife and my son.

RASHA BASHA: I fled Syria
from thuggish regime

that imprisoned, raped, torture
its own citizens for no reason.

SHADI MARTINI: I was
a general manager

of a hospital in Aleppo, Syria
when the uprising started.

And in Syria I took the decision
to treat people who are being

shot in demonstrations, and to
help my colleagues establish

secret facilities
to treat people

who are deprived of their
right to get medical treatment.

That put me a lot
with the government.

And when our network
was discovered
I had to flee the country.

SUZANNE AKHRAS SAHLOUL: So when
we came in the summer of 1982
to visit our grandparents, my--

my mother at that
time felt she did not

want to go back
because you know,

there weren't that
many opportunities.

And at that time there
was the first uprising

against the father of the
dictator, the current dictator,
which is Hafez al-Assad.

So because of that, my
mother decided that she
didn't want to go back.

And she was worried
about my sisters
and I. I was the youngest.

And so she convinced
my father to--
to come to the US.

ZUBAIR RUSHK: Before 2011
Kurd Syrian considered
as a second-class citizen.

We not allowed to
speak our language.

We not allowed to
teach our kids culture.

I create school in my
own house teaching kids

around four year
students, teaching culture
and history and language.

The government
find out my school

and they put me in
jail for seven months.

In those seven months they
tortured me very badly

to the point that I had PSTD
and losing partial of my memory
due to torture.
